I am writing to express my support for the Global Change Research Improvement Act of 2007. This bill would make important changes to the Global Change Research Act of 1990, which was landmark legislation that established a coordinated federal program to study global change.

The bill would rename the Committee on Earth and Environmental Sciences as the Committee on Global Change Research, and it would replace the Federal Coordinating Council on Science, Engineering, and Technology with the National Science and Technology Council. These changes would make the federal government's global change research program more efficient and effective.

The bill would also define "global change" as "changes in the Earth's environment that are caused by human activities and that have the potential to affect human health, welfare, or ecosystems." This definition is important because it clarifies the scope of the federal government's global change research program.

I urge you to support the Global Change Research Improvement Act of 2007. This bill would make important changes to the Global Change Research Act of 1990, and it would help the United States to better understand and address the challenges of global change.

I am writing in support of the Climate Neutral Electricity Generation Act of 2007. This bill would provide a tax credit for investment in climate neutral combustion facilities, which are facilities that burn matter to produce electricity while capturing and using the carbon dioxide released during combustion to recover hydrocarbon fuel. These facilities would produce no emissions of mercury or greenhouse gases and no emissions that form fine particulate, smog, or acid rain.

Climate neutral combustion facilities are an important step towards reducing our reliance on fossil fuels and mitigating climate change. They offer a clean, efficient, and sustainable way to generate electricity. I urge you to support this bill.

I am writing in support of the Veterans Cold Weather Injury Compensation Act. As a veteran who served in Alaska, I am all too familiar with the dangers of cold weather exposure. I have seen firsthand the devastating effects that cold weather can have on a person's health, both physically and mentally.

The Veterans Cold Weather Injury Compensation Act would provide much-needed assistance to veterans who have been injured as a result of cold weather exposure. The bill would create a registry of veterans who were exposed to sustained periods of extremely cold weather, and it would require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to determine the association, if any, between the disabilities of such veterans and the exposure to such weather. The bill would also presume certain disabilities to be service-connected for veterans who were exposed to cold weather during their service.

I believe that this bill is a long overdue step in providing justice to veterans who have been injured as a result of cold weather exposure. I urge you to support this important legislation.
